Literature Review: The visual system is a remarkable feat of biological engineering, capable of processing vast amounts of information to create a coherent representation of the world. Two prominent theories have emerged to explain how the brain accomplishes this task: efficient coding and predictive coding. This literature review explores the relationship between these two paradigms and their complementary roles in visual processing.Efficient coding, first proposed by Horace Barlow in 1961, posits that the brain's neural representations are optimized to minimize redundancy and maximize information transmission given limited neural resources. This hypothesis suggests that the visual system has evolved to exploit statistical regularities in natural scenes, discarding predictable information and focusing on the most informative aspects of the visual input.Numerous studies have provided evidence supporting the efficient coding hypothesis in various aspects of visual processing. For instance, Olshausen and Field demonstrated that sparse coding, a form of efficient coding, can explain the receptive field properties of neurons in the primary visual cortex (V1). Their work showed that when trained on natural images, artificial neural networks develop receptive fields remarkably similar to those observed in biological V1 neurons.Building on this foundation, Vinje and Gallant found that V1 neurons exhibit increased sparseness and independence in their responses when stimulated with natural scenes compared to artificial stimuli. This finding suggests that the visual system is indeed optimized for processing natural visual inputs, aligning with the predictions of efficient coding theory.While efficient coding focuses on optimizing information transmission, predictive coding emphasizes the brain's ability to generate predictions about future sensory inputs. This theory, popularized by Rao and Ballard, proposes that the brain continually generates and updates internal models of the world, using these models to predict incoming sensory information and focusing processing resources on unexpected or novel stimuli.The predictive coding framework has gained substantial support from neuroimaging and electrophysiological studies. For example, Alink et al. used fMRI to show that visual cortex activity is reduced when stimuli are predictable, suggesting that the brain processes primarily prediction errors rather than raw sensory input. Similarly, Kok et al. demonstrated that expected visual stimuli elicit weaker neural responses but contain more information about the stimulus, indicating a more efficient neural representation of predicted inputs.At first glance, efficient coding and predictive coding may seem at odds with each other. Efficient coding emphasizes discarding predictable information, while predictive coding focuses on generating and updating predictions. However, recent research suggests that these two paradigms are complementary and often operate on different aspects of visual input.Chalk et al. proposed an integrated framework combining efficient and predictive coding principles. They demonstrated that a single neural network could simultaneously optimize for both efficient representation and accurate prediction of future states. This work suggests that the brain may employ a hybrid strategy, efficiently encoding current sensory information while also maintaining predictive capabilities.The information bottleneck theory, introduced by Tishby et al., provides a potential bridge between efficient and predictive coding. This theory formalizes the trade-off between compressing sensory input and preserving information relevant for future predictions. Recent work by Alemi et al. has shown how the information bottleneck principle can be applied to deep neural networks, offering insights into how biological visual systems might balance efficiency and predictive power.Empirical evidence for the integration of efficient and predictive coding in the visual system comes from studies of neural adaptation. For instance, Hosoya et al. found that retinal ganglion cells dynamically adjust their receptive fields based on the statistics of recent visual input, optimizing both coding efficiency and predictive power. This adaptive behavior suggests that the visual system continuously balances the demands of efficient representation and accurate prediction.Furthermore, research on the hierarchical organization of the visual cortex provides additional support for the complementary nature of efficient and predictive coding. Friston proposed that higher-level visual areas generate predictions about lower-level sensory inputs, with each level of the hierarchy optimizing its representations based on both bottom-up sensory information and top-down predictions. This hierarchical predictive coding framework incorporates elements of both efficient coding and prediction.In conclusion, while efficient coding and predictive coding were initially developed as separate theories, recent research suggests that they are complementary aspects of visual processing. The visual system appears to employ both strategies, efficiently encoding sensory information while simultaneously generating and updating predictions about future inputs. As our understanding of these processes deepens, we may uncover new insights into how the brain balances the competing demands of efficiency and prediction in visual perception. Future research should focus on developing integrated models that capture both aspects of neural coding and exploring how these principles apply to other sensory modalities and cognitive functions.
